In 1913, the first direct federal-income-tax was imposed upon your pocketbook by Congress. This motion succeeded only after the much debated 16th Amendment had been ratified and accepted by the states. (An action that is now thought to have been unlawfully executed!) Anyhow, the original income tax was INCREDIBLY low---only a mere, yet principally wrong, ONE-PERCENT! Moreover, this tax was only applicable to incomes in excess of $20,000(1913), which calculates out to a little under $400,000 in 2004, after being adjusted for inflation. Suprising? I thought so. The Founding Fathers had forseen the possibility of Congress instating taxes for essential purposes, yet they were horrified at the suggestion of a Massachusets Senator who implied that Congress may, at one time, abuse the Constitutonal ability to lay taxes(section 8, clause 1) by levying a direct income tax. Additionally, when that Senator suggested that the aforesaid tax could reach levels as high as 20%, he was flaty refuted by Alexander Hamilton who angrily stated that no elected Congress could possibly be so lacking in fairness, justice and patriotism. Nevertheless, we have seen the Feds pulling up SIXTY-FIVE percent of your annual paycheck! (1970's) So, what all this really means is this: every year, hundreds of millions of Americans citizens are financially plundered by the very governing body they elected to office.
